newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish PM, economists welcome union's pay pledge.
newsitem.headline: Swedish PM, economists welcome union's pay pledge.

text.p: Swedish economists joined Prime Minister Goran Persson in welcoming major retail union Handels' proposal Thursday to freeze a current wage pact, with moderate pay rises, until the year 2000.
Persson said other unions might follow Handels' lead.
"I don't think it's with no prospect of others following," Persson told journalists after a session in parliament.

The union and retail employers made a joint declaration in the Dagens Nyheter daily on Thursday calling on workers and industry to extend existing pay agreements and give politicians room to fight unemployment without boosting inflation.
"It's not sure the freeze will take place at all if other unions choose not to follow. But the declaration shows there is a new way of thinking", Nordbanken chief economist Olle Djerf said.
Although economists agreed that the proposal was encouraging they differed in their expectations for unemployment.

"The European labour crisis is unlikely to be solved by moves like this. The main problem is flexibility," Paine Webber's James McKay said. "The outlook is still poor...I think we will see seasonally adjusted unemployment hitting bottom sometime in 1998 at 6.5-7 percent before it heads up again."

"You have to generate more flexibility at the same time as loyalty is maintained...And you have to use the carrot instead of the stick. The U.S. uses the stick", Keld Holm, senior international economist at Lehman Brothers said.
Some economists saw generous welfare benefits as the biggest threat to full employment while other looked to the U.S. labour market, with greater wage differentials, as a model.

Others said that Sweden should commit itself to building a highly-educated workforce able to command a premium on the global labour market, as it would not be able to compete on price with cut-rate workers from developing countries.
Hubert Fromlet, chief economist at Sparbanken, emphasised the importance of stable and consistent government policies.
"There can't be policies which make yields turn back up. Ideological antagonism must come second," Fromlet said.
Unemployment in Sweden was 8.8 percent in February, unchanged from a month earlier.
